abstract.p: Continuing Laurel Richardson’s call to use writing as my method and specifically utilizing poetic inquiry, “For Trayvon Martin” represents my interpretation of this tragedy filtered through a lens shaped by an epistemology of color, the history of racism, and local and national news reports both in print and on-line, as well as informal conversations with a wide variety of family, friends, and colleagues. The work’s theoretical frame incorporates critical pedagogy, critical race theory, and imagination-intellect theory. This piece investigates the impact of racial profiling and a Stand your Ground law supposedly designed to protect Florida citizens who are instead falling victim to it.

body.p: beside each body like a macabre memory
it appears after bullets fly pierce
It’s part of a crime scene po-lice
have investigated before they get to each new
Local news denies this new way of lynching
their right to bear arms intact.
No one noticed the broken bottle
of tea kicked over by the cop
who took the caution tape down
and every skittle scattered when he was shot
picked up and placed in an individual
like fear in a teen’s eyes
each side as certain as the other
bond what a real judge thought
for an apology that never happens
an empty bag as George walks out
with wooden teeth and the 200,000 dollars

bio.title: Bio
bio.p: Mary E. Weems is poet, playwright, and imagination-intellect theorist working in interpretive methods. She’s also an Assistant Professor in the Department of Education and Allied Studies at John Carroll University. Her new book “Writings of Healing and Resistance: Empathy and the Imagination-Intellect” is forthcoming from Peter Lang, and her book of poems “For(e)closure” was a finalist in the 2011 Main Street Poetry Book Contest and will be published.
